awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Designing Nitrogen Coordinated Single Atomic Metal Electrocatalysts for Selective CO2 Reduction to CO
awd_abstract_narration:
Fossil fuels (i.e., coal, petroleum, and natural gas) are still today's primary energy sources, but their utilization increases carbon emissions.  Technologies that can convert waste carbon dioxide (CO2) into value-added chemicals have great economic and societal importance for realizing a sustainable energy future.  Electricity, generated from sunlight, offers a potential sustainable route for CO2 conversion to chemicals, but present electrochemical approaches require expensive precious metals as catalysts. The project will focus on discovery of cost-effective alternatives to the precious metal catalysts while contributing to U.S. research leadership in energy utilization.   The project will impact a broad range of technology related to renewable energy, water usage, transportation, and defense. Moreover, the research results will be incorporated into curriculum development, student mentoring, and educational outreach to high-school teachers and students. This award will also broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in conducting research and will positively impact higher education in science and engineering disciplines.

Nitrogen coordinated single atomic metal (e.g. iron, cobalt, or nickel) is a new type of electrocatalyst that has demonstrated impressive activity and relatively high selectivity for electrochemical reduction of CO2 to carbon monoxide (CO) in recent research.  However, the chemical nature of the active sites as well as the catalytic mechanisms for CO2 reduction in such complex catalyst systems are not fully understood. In addition, the factors controlling selectivity to CO2 reduction versus the competitive water reduction reaction are not well known. This research aims to provide fundamental understanding of rationally designed nitrogen coordinated single atomic metal sites embedded in a carbon framework and to elucidate the relationship between the synthesis, properties and performance of the catalysts in selective CO2 reduction into CO. The research team will 1) predict the active sites using first-principles calculation methods, 2) synthesize the catalysts containing the predicted active sites and local carbon structures, 3) conduct comprehensive characterization of the chemical properties, structure, and morphology of the synthesized catalysts, and 4) measure the performance of the synthesized catalysts for electrochemical CO2 reduction. This research will provide insights on how to achieve the highest possible activity and selectivity of the catalysts for CO2 reduction to CO through tuning the coordination environment of the central metal-nitrogen atom and the local carbon structure.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF PITTSBURGH - OF THE COMMONWEALTH SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

por.por_cntn:
Massive use of fossil fuels (i.e., coal, petroleum, and natural gas) as the primary energy sources in our society leads to an increase in the emissions of greenhouse gases (e.g., CO2) into the atmosphere and serious environmental issues such as climate changes.  Hence, technologies that can convert waste CO2 into value-added chemicals have great economic and societal importance for mitigating environmental issues associated with the increasing consumption of fossil fuels. The CO2 reduction is a kinetically slow process and thus requires catalysts to increase the rate of reaction. At present, precious metals (e.g. gold, silver, and palladium) are effective catalysts for electrochemical reduction of CO2. However, their high cost hampers the wide implementation of the technology. This award supports research to acquire fundamental knowledge for the development of cost-effective catalysts based on earth abundant elements yet exhibiting excellent performance for electrochemical reduction of CO2. Nitrogen coordinated single atomic metal (e.g. iron, cobalt, or nickel) doped carbon (denoted as M-N-C) is a new type of electrocatalyst that exhibits impressive activity and relatively high selectivity for electrochemical reduction of CO2 to carbon monoxide (CO).  However, the chemical nature of the possible active sites, the catalytic mechanisms for CO2 reduction, and the suppression of the competitive water reduction reaction to form hydrogen in such complex catalyst systems are not fully understood. The hypothesis of the project is that the activity and selectivity of the M-N-C catalysts for CO2 reduction to CO are determined by the atomic M-Nx moieties dispersed into carbon layers and can be improved by tuning the type of central M, N coordination, and local carbon structure. To examine this hypothesis, the research team have performed the first-principles density functional theory calculations to predict the free energy evolution of CO2 reduction reactions as well as the electrochemical stability and selectivity of the modelled M-Nx active sites in M-N-C electrocatalysts, validated the computational predictions against the characterization and measurement results from the experimental collaborators, and proposed new strategies for catalyst performance enhancement. The results from this research enable the development of economical yet high-performance technology for reduction of CO2 into value-added chemicals, and hence benefit the U.S. economy and society.

Intellectual Merit: In this project, the first-principles density functional theory calculations have been applied to obtain fundamental knowledge of how to achieve the highest possible activity and selectivity of the catalysts for CO2 reduction to CO through tuning the type of central metal-nitrogen coordination and the local carbon structure. Specifically, the notable results from this research are that (1) introduction of S dopants can improve both the selectivity and activity of Fe-N-C catalysts for CO2 reduction because S dopants would donate electron to adjacent FeN4 active sites; (2) the FeN4 active sites on the edge of a carbon layer would exhibit better selectivity for CO2 reduction than the FeN4 sites embedded inside a carbon layer; (3) introduction of pores and edges to Fe-N-C catalysts could enhance the reactivity of CO2 reduction to CO and promote CO desorption significantly; (4) compressive strain in the carbon layer is beneficial for enhancing the both activity and selectivity of Ni-N-C catalysts for CO2 reduction; and (5) an optimal synergy between the two metal atoms in a diatomic (Fe,Ni)N6 site could lead to both enhanced activity and good selectivity toward CO2 reduction to CO in Fe, Ni dual metal N-doped carbon catalysts.  

Broader Impacts: The project produces and disseminates new knowledge of developing novel catalysts for electrochemical reactions relevant to sustainability and energy, and thus has an impact on a broad range of fields including renewable energy, water usage, transportation, and defense, which demand advanced electrocatalyst-based technologies. The computation tools developed in this project have been distributed in academic community to predict the activity, stability, and selectivity of electrocatalysts for oxygen reduction and nitrogen reduction, the atomistic structure and catalytic activity of high entropy alloy nanoparticles, and the catalytic activity of bimetallic catalyst nanoparticles. Twelve research articles have been published in peer-reviewed scientific journals, and multiple technical presentations have been delivered at international conferences. The research results have been added as teaching materials of graduate and undergraduate courses. Through the entire life of the award, two PhD graduate students, two MS graduate students, and six undergraduate students receive the research training in computational materials science. Moreover, the research results have been incorporated into curriculum enhancement, student training, industrial collaboration, and an educational outreach program.

This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

 


Last Modified: 11/04/2021
Modified by: Guofeng Wang
